lines.text: [while Regret and Cutter are tied up as prisoners]
I wonder if they know how much trouble they're in.
Let him make a run for it, I'd say to myself.
And then what would you say?
And then I'd say back to myself, you can't let him run. You swore an oath whent they put that badge on you.
And that's important to you?
I said I swore an oath.
Words!
Mon-sewer, words are what men live by... words they say and mean.
How do you know you killed him?
There wasn't time not to!
[last lines]
Well, Mon-Soor, looks like I've lost you again.
Mr. McBaine, or whatever your name is, we'll miss you. We've kinda gotten used to you.
Big Jake, don't forget to mend those fences!
never go to bed without makin' a profit.
Mon-sewer, you may not live long enough to hang.
stimulation, relaxation, pleasant association, and interesting conversation.
Shut your mouth.
Now that I can look back on it, I can see how bad it was. That's how I came to give myself up.
Yep, after breaking one ranger's jaw and slicing up two others with a Bowie knife.
Oh, I feel bad about that. I wasn't using my head.
You used everything else! Feet, fist and teeth!
Yes, sir. But them rangers won me over. If I had just known men like that, I might never have fell in with bad companions.
I'll bet he was a man to stand aside from when he was young and limber.
It's time we both quit, Crow. You don't like losing to me, and I don't like winning from you.
You see those dark markings? A cross patch over light. It makes him look like a rattler. But you can see a thousand like him. But when you see your first rattlesnake, you'll know the difference.
You still haven't told me how you tell a Commanche from a tame Indian.
Just like your first rattler. One look and you'll know.
Most say, except for them who are unfair minded, that I have the finest legal mind in the entire southwest. So you can have faith in your lawyer, son. How much money you got?
lines.character: Circuit Court Judge Thaddeus Jackson Breen

lines.text: I don't have any.
Well, I'm beginning to doubt your chances against the law.
lines.character: Circuit Court Judge Thaddeus Jackson Breen

lines.text: Major here has told me what your troubles are. I've been thinking it over and in light of my forty years experience in legal jurisprudence, I have come to the positive conclusion that there ain't no way to do this legal and honest... but being good sensible Texans, we'll do it illegal and dishonest! Now all the boys here in the room have agreed to sign a paper I have prepared. They all are going to commit perjury. That's legal language for just a plain, dumb blasted lie.
lines.character: Circuit Court Judge Thaddeus Jackson Breen

lines.text: It would break my heart if I had to put a bullet in your back.
It would make me sad also.
You think I'm simple minded.
Yes, I think you're simple minded.
Well, don't make a point of saying it too often... and once more would be too often!
Gentlemen, let's remember we're gentlemen.
Forget it! He's just spittin' out words to see where they splatter.
Am I to believe that you weighed and appraised and then selected me out of all the men on this boat?
Do not be too conceited. It's not a very large boat.
[last lines]
Take care of yourself, Big Jake. We've sort of gotten used to you.
Give me one good reason why you don't marry that woman.
Why don't you mind your own business?
[pause]
I don't have one good reason.
[first lines]
Since there is no reconciliation, we proceed. You will please stand with your backs to one another.
It may amuse you to know, monsieur, I never believed you cheated at cards.
Well, maybe I don't have your sense of humor.
There's a lady who prefers your attentions to mine. I intend to... simplify her choice.
Rachel?
[Emil snickers]
Margo? No.

When I begin to count, you will each take 10 paces. You will turn and fire on the count of 10. If either man stops or turns before the count of 10, it will be my distasteful duty to shoot him down. Good luck.
Thanks.
Are we going somewhere?
Trial.
Trial?
To see whether you live or die. You'll die.
I always figured to die. The question is when.
Many others will be sorry to see you hang.
Hang? They've never enforced the laws against dueling before.

The son of Judge Bouvier has never been killed before. Yes, most certainly, he will have you arrested before nightfall and hanged before the week is out. I'm sorry, it will take the incentive out of dueling.
Well, I wouldn't want to spoil it for the rest of you.
McBaine, you try walking out on me now, see how far you get, deal or no deal.
You need me as much as I need you, Crow. Just give that some thought.
